THE FRENCH DEBT jNote by the Chancellor of the Exchequer.I circulate for the information of my colleagues the translation of a letter which I have received from Monsieur Gaillaux on the subject of the French Debt to this country,W..S.C oTreasury Chambers.17th September? 1925aMINISTRY OF FINANCE.4th September. 1925oDear Mr a Churchill,You were good enough on the 25th August to send me a personal letter in whioh it was stated that the British Cabinet reduced to 12-1 millions, the amount of the annuity which His Ma jestys s Government requires to receive for 62 years from the French Government in repayment of their DehtB In the same letter a slightly different financial arrangement was contemplated- worked out in connection with the Dawes plan0I have submitted these views to the Council of Ministers and have the honour to inform you that the figures fixed by the British Government do not give rise to any objection of principle on the part of the French Government. The amount required hy the British Government being thus settled, the French Cabinet has no doubt that an agreement both can and should be reached between the two Powers upon the other questions (essential both in their opinion and in yours) which were discussed between us0 You may rest assured that the French Government will leave nothing undone in order to achieve this result.I am, dear Mre Churchill,Yours very sincerely, J, CAILIAUX.
